biogHist.p: Ann MacLellan was the daughter of John (born c. 1757), farmer and tailor, and Christina née Macmillan (born c. 1767). She was born c. 1808, seemingly the second of five children, two other daughters called Mary, and two sons, John and Angus.

In 1847 Ann married Hector MacIsaac (c. 1797–1878), joiner, the son of Roderick and Ann née Macintyre. Roderick was a tenant at Lianacuidh in Iochdar. The couple, then recorded as being at Bòrnais Iochdrach, had one child, Marion, born 23 November 1848. By 1861 the family are living at Àird na Mòine, Iochdar, and ten years later they are recorded at Àird Mhór (at present-day number 4) in the same district.

Hector MacIsaac was one of the most celebrated seanchaidhean of the island in his day, possessing a rich store of Fenian narratives, most of which he had learnt from the itinerant catechist Roderick MacQuien, Ruairidh Ruadh. Alexander Carmichael had been recording from him since July 1865, and it is clear that a rapport had been established between the young collector and the older couple.

Although a relatively frequent visitor to the household, Alexander Carmichael apparently recorded Anna MacIsaac on just two occasions. Firstly, during 1865 he seems to have taken down a version of MacLeod’s Lullaby, Tàladh MhicLeòid [Carmina Gadelica v, 214–15, 226, 227]. Secondly, he recorded at greater length from her on 16 October 1867. The original field notes from these two occasions have not survived, but later transcripts of the second, including a reconstruction of her conversation to him [CW87/22-28], suggest that she began by presenting Carmichael with a Eàrna Mhoire or Molucca Bean, a prized family heirloom cherished for its powers in protecting women in childbirth. Carmichael was shortly to marry Mary Frances Macbean, and it is likely that the bean was the old lady’s wedding gift to the new couple. Along with it, Anna MacIsaac recited a charm to be recited thrice while the child was being born.

Carmichael’s interest was clearly picqued, as Ann MacIsaac went on to give the collector a charm she described – possibly in error – as An Eàrr-Thalmhainn or yarrow charm [cf. CG i, 68–9; it is interesting that Carmichael ascribed, or probably misascribed, to Ann MacIsaac a yarrow charm not in extant manuscripts, CG ii, 94–5], followed by a series of four charms to protect cattle: Eòlas an Tairbhein, probably against warble fly; Eòlas a’ Bhun-Deirg, against Red Water Disease; Eòlas na Ruaidh, against rose or erysipelas; and Eòlas an t-Sniòmh, the familiar ‘bone to bone’ charm – the implication being, of course, that she was an active charmer. By the time the recording session had ended, Alexander Carmichael had noted six items, almost as many vernacular charm texts as had been written down in Scottish Gaelic during the previous three centuries.

Despite the importance of the items which she had given Carmichael, the only other reference to Ann MacIsaac in the collection is a marginal note naming her and her husband, dated 16 December 1874 [CW380 fo.90v].

Ann MacIsaac outlived her husband, who died of old age on 11 July 1878. In the 1881 census she is described as living alone as a pauper in her single-roomed house in Àird Mhòr. There she died alone two years later, on 29 January 1883, of ‘old age & infirmity’. Her death certificate was not certified, but was signed by her daughter, now Marion MacQuarrie.
